dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Oh for crying out loud. No no wait, hear me out. The S&P, it hit a new record close, okay? Like, a new record. Right. And the Dow’s up five hundred points.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh for crying out loud. No no wait, hear me out. The S&P, it hit a new record close, okay? Like, a new record. Right. And the Dow's up five hundred points.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The S&P 500 index rose 1.1% on Wednesday, hitting a new record closing high of 3334.69 and fully erasing its losses stemming from fears over the coronavirus... The Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped nearly 500 points, gaining 1.7%...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: So what? The S&P was just down, what, last week? It's just a bounce.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So what? The S&P was just down, what, last week? It's just a bounce.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...a huge sell-off on coronavirus fears last Friday when the Dow shed 600 points and posted its worst single-day drop since August 2019, while the S&P 500 saw its largest decline since October.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Well, yeah, but it's recovering almost all of its virus-related losses from the last two weeks, though. That's, uh, that's pretty good, right? Pretty good.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, yeah, but it's recovering almost all of its virus-related losses from the last two weeks, though. That's, uh, that's pretty good, right? Pretty good.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The stock market continued to rally higher on Wednesday, as the S&P 500 hit a new record close and the Dow rose almost 500 points, with stocks now recovering most of their losses related to the coronavirus during the past two weeks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: While, like, the actual virus is, you know, out there being worse than SARS. Twenty-five thousand infected. Four hundred ninety dead.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: While, like, the actual virus is, you know, out there being worse than S A R S. Twenty-five thousand infected. Four hundred ninety dead.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The fast-spreading and deadly coronavirus has now outpaced the level of severity seen with the 2002-2003 SARS outbreak. As of Wednesday, the disease has infected nearly 25,000 people and killed 490.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but economists are still optimistic! And consumer confidence? It's unexpectedly strong, which is, like, a huge deal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but economists are still optimistic! And consumer confidence? It's unexpectedly strong, which is, like, a huge deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Sure, sure. Meanwhile, Tesla shares just tanked almost twenty percent. Worst day ever. Production concerns in Shanghai, you know.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Sure, sure. Meanwhile, Tesla shares just tanked almost twenty percent. Worst day ever. Production concerns in Shanghai, you know.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Nasdaq was held back in large part because Tesla shares, which soared up to 50% earlier this week, plunged by almost 20% on Wednesday—its worst day ever—amid reports that the coronavirus would impact production and deliveries at its factory in Shanghai, China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, yeah, that’s true, the Nasdaq kind of lagged because of that. But it's still up over seventy percent for the year. Analysts are still, uh, super bullish on its long-term.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, yeah, that's true, the Nasdaq kind of lagged because of that. But it's still up over seventy percent for the year. Analysts are still, uh, super bullish on its long-term.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Nasdaq Composite index, on the other hand, lagged both the Dow and S&P 500... Even with Wednesday’s record plunge, Tesla stock is still up more than 70% in 2020.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Long-term. Whatever. Are we talking about real things here? Or just numbers going up and down for the rich guys?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Long-term. Whatever. Are we talking about real things here? Or just numbers going up and down for the rich guys?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: No! No, look at this! US private payrolls, January? Up almost three hundred thousand! That’s, like, double what they expected. Biggest gain in five years. That helps real people, no?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No! No, look at this! U S private payrolls, January? Up almost three hundred thousand! That's, like, double what they expected. Biggest gain in five years. That helps real people, no?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Adding to the good news for the market on Wednesday was a report from ADP and Moody’s Analytics, which said that U.S. private payrolls rose by 291,000 in January—almost twice the expected number and the biggest monthly payroll gain in almost five years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: More jobs, great. So we just forget about the looming global pandemic, then? The WHO even said, like, it's pretty severe.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: More jobs, great. So we just forget about the looming global pandemic, then? The W H O even said, like, it's pretty severe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: They did, but they also said to maintain supply chains, try to minimize economic disruption. It's about, uh, perspective. Adam Crisafulli, he said the bullish narrative, it's back in control.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They did, but they also said to maintain supply chains, try to minimize economic disruption. It's about, uh, perspective. Adam Crisafulli, he said the bullish narrative, it's back in control.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: “The bullish narrative that’s been driving stocks since late 2019 is firmly back in control of the tape after taking a brief pause during the final days of January,” Vital Knowledge founder Adam Crisafulli wrote in a note on Wednesday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, Crisafulli. Right. The bullish narrative is back. While, uh, travel restrictions and work stoppages are gonna have a material impact on global growth. His words, not mine.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, Crisafulli. Right. The bullish narrative is back. While, uh, travel restrictions and work stoppages are gonna have a material impact on global growth. His words, not mine.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The coronavirus-linked work stoppages and travel restrictions will have a “material impact” on global growth, Crisafulli recently predicted.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but only in the first quarter, they think! A strong rebound is expected in the second half. That's what, uh, that's what many experts are saying.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but only in the first quarter, they think! A strong rebound is expected in the second half. That's what, uh, that's what many experts are saying.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Experts. Uh huh. So it’s all fine. Everything’s just gonna be fine then, huh? Just, ignore the 500 deaths.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Experts. Uh huh. So it's all fine. Everything's just gonna be fine then, huh? Just, ignore the five hundred deaths.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As of Wednesday, the disease has infected nearly 25,000 people and killed 490.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: No, not ignore it. But the market, it's showing resilience, you know? It bounced back from that huge sell-off last Friday. That's... that's something, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, not ignore it. But the market, it's showing resilience, you know? It bounced back from that huge sell-off last Friday. That's... that's something, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: All three major indexes have now posted gains for the third day in a row, marking a recovery from a huge sell-off on coronavirus fears last Friday when the Dow shed 600 points...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I guess. Until it, uh, crashes again next week.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I guess. Until it, uh, crashes again next week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Hey, the S&P's positive for 2020! It's up 1.2%! That's, that's good news!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey, the S&P's positive for twenty twenty! It's up one point two percent! That's, that's good news!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The S&P 500 has now fully recovered from its coronavirus-related losses, turning positive for 2020 so far. The index is now up 1.2% for the year.
